abstract.text: A view that displays standardized onboarding instructions to direct users toward a specific goal.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: This view offers your users a standardized onboarding routine. You can configure this view to automatically display during session initialization and in limited tracking situations, while giving the user specific instructions that best facilitate ARKit’s world tracking.
These illustrations show overlay views with horizontal- and vertical-plane goals, indicating that the user should begin moving the device:
These illustrations show overlay views indicating that the user should continue moving the phone or change the speed with which they move it:

When you start your app, the coaching overlay asks the user to move the device in ways that help ARKit establish tracking. When you choose a specific goal like finding a plane, the view tailors its instructions accordingly. After the coaching overlay determines the goal has been met and no further coaching is required, it hides from the user’s view.
For an example app that uses the coaching overlay, see
is enabled and therefore you should override
to determine whether coaching is in progress. Coordinate your actions to help the user focus on these instructions, for example, by hiding any UI that’s not necessary while the session reinitializes.

), ARKit attempts to restore your session if any interruptions degrade your app’s tracking state. In this event, the coaching overlay presents itself and gives the user instructions to assist ARKit with relocalizing.
During this time, the coaching overlay includes a button that lets the user indicate they’d like to start over rather than restore the session.
ARKit notifies you when the user presses Start Over by calling your delegate’s
function. Implement this callback if your app requires any custom actions to restart the AR experience.

code: // Custom actions to restart the AR experience.

inlineContent.text: , the coaching overlay responds to the Start Over button by resetting tracking, which also removes any existing anchors.
For more information about relocalization, see

abstract.text: Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
A view that displays standardized onboarding instructions to direct users toward a specific goal.
The options that specify your app’s tracking requirements.
A flag that indicates whether the coaching view activates automatically, depending on the current session state.
An object you supply that implements coaching event callbacks.
A field that indicates your app’s tracking requirements.
A flag that indicates whether coaching is in progress.
The session this view uses to provide coaching.
An object you designate that provides the current session.
Controls whether coaching is in progress.
A set of callbacks you implement to be notified of coaching events.
Tells you when the user taps the coaching overlay view’s Start Over button while the session is relocalizing.
Tells you when the coaching overlay view activates.
A view that blends virtual 3D content from SceneKit into your augmented reality experience.
A view that blends virtual 2D content from SpriteKit into the 3D space of an augmented reality experience.
Asks the delegate whether to attempt recovery of world-tracking state after an interruption.
Keep the user informed on the current session state and recover from interruptions.

doc://com.apple.arkit/documentation/ARKi.title: Managing Session Life Cycle and Tracking Quality

abstract.text: Place virtual content at tracked, real-world locations, and enable the user to interact with virtual content by using gestures.
A view that enables you to display an AR experience with RealityKit.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.

media-3394474.alt: Button that enables the user to indicate they’d like to start over rather than restore the session.

media-3394488.alt: User instruction to return to the user’s previous location so ARKit can restore the session.

media-3403211.alt: Illustration showing two overlay views. The view at the left indicates that the device is moving and the user should continue moving it. The view at the right indicates that the device is moving too fast and the user should move it more slowly.

media-3403212.alt: Illustration showing two overlay views. The view at the left shows a horizontal plane, and the view at the right shows a vertical plane. Both views indicate that the user should begin moving the device.
